importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the citizen lobby day in Washington, D.C., when over 500 volunteers, including those from New York, visited congressional offices to advocate for cancer research, screening, and insurance subsidies.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame covers the key events of the cancer advocacy campaign, including the lobbying event on Capitol Hill and the subsequent candlelight vigil on the National Mall, which highlighted the shared experience of cancer survivors across political lines.

keyTakeAways: Cancer survivors from diverse political backgrounds united in Washington, D.C., to lobby Congress despite partisan divides.
The shared experience of surviving or being affected by cancer transcends political differences, creating a rare moment of bipartisan unity.
Despite political gridlock, both Democrats and Republicans supported increased cancer research funding and expanded access to cancer screening.
Extension of ACA health insurance subsidies remained a contentious issue, especially among Republican lawmakers, but was not the only focus of the advocacy efforts.
The event included a candlelight vigil with 10,000 tea lights honoring individuals affected by cancer, symbolizing collective grief and solidarity.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Hundreds of cancer survivors from across the U.S., including individuals from New York such as Mary Catherine Johnson, Lexy Mealing, and Katie Martin, united in Washington, D.C., to lobby Congress during a citizen advocacy event organized by the American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network. Despite their differing political affiliations—Johnson voted for Donald Trump three times, Mealing is a Democrat, and Manna is a self-described Reagan Republican—the volunteers transcended partisan divides, emphasizing that cancer does not care about political ideology. Their shared experience of surviving or being affected by cancer created a powerful bond, enabling them to focus on common goals: increased funding for cancer research, expanded access to screening, and support for ACA health insurance subsidies. Although the extension of subsidies remained controversial among Republican lawmakers, both parties supported research funding and screening initiatives. The event culminated in a candlelight vigil on the National Mall, honoring 10,000 individuals affected by cancer. The story illustrates how personal health experiences can foster bipartisan cooperation in a politically divided environment.
title: 'Cancer doesn't care': Patients pushed past divisive politics to lobby Congress
